choices.text: Insulin is important to control fetal growth
Human fetal growth is rapid in the first half of intrauterine life

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding human growth except?
questions.solution:
There is a set of principles that characterizes the pattern and process of growth and development. Typical development is a predictable and orderly process; Although there are individual differences in children's personalities, activity levels, and timing of developmental milestones, the principles and characteristics of development have universal patterns.

  1. Development proceeds from the head downward.
    1. This is called the cephalocaudal principle. This principle describes the direction of growth and development. According to this principle, the child gains control of the head first, then the arms, and then the legs.
  2. Development proceeds from the center of the body outward.
    1. This is the principle of proximodistal development that also describes the direction of development. This means that the spinal cord develops before outer parts of the body. The child's arms develop before the hands and the hands and feet develop before the fingers and toes. Finger and toe muscles (used in fine motor dexterity) are the last to develop in physical development.
  3. Development depends on maturation and learning.
    1. Maturation refers to the sequential characteristic of biological growth and development. The biological changes occur in sequential order and give children new abilities.
  4. Development proceeds from the simple (concrete) to the more complex- orthogenetic principle
  5. Growth and development is a continuous process.
    1. As a child develops, he or she adds to the skills already acquired and the new skills become the basis for further achievement and mastery of skills. Most children follow a similar pattern. Also, one stage of development lays the foundation for the next stage of development.
  6. Growth and development proceed from the general to specific.
    1. Growth occurs from large muscle movements to more refined (smaller) muscle movements.
  7. There are individual rates of growth and development.
    1. Each child is different and the rates at which individual children grow is different. Although the patterns and sequences for growth and development are usually the same for all children, the rates at which individual children reach developmental stages will be different.

Reference: Illingworth's The Development of the Infant and Young Child: Normal and Abnormal, 11e, page 4

questions.text: A child was suspected to be having Kwashiorkor. Which of the following are considered specific, hallmark features?
questions.solution:
Severe acute malnutrition (SAM), also known as "severe wasting and/or nutritional edema", is associated with one of two classical syndromes: marasmus (wasting syndrome) and kwashiorkor (edematous malnutrition), or a combination of the two (marasmic kwashiorkor).

Kwashiorkor (edematous malnutrition) -

  • Kwashiorkor is characterized by symmetricperipheral pitting edema that begins in the most dependent regions and proceeds cranially as time progresses, often involving the presacral area, genitalia, and periorbital area, with or without anasarca (severe generalized edema).
  • There is marked muscle atrophy with normal or even increased body fat.
  • Malnutrition is considered severe if any edema is present, regardless of other anthropometric values.

Other physical examination findings include:

  • Apathetic, listless affect
  • Rounded prominence of the cheeks ("moon face")
  • Pursed appearance of the mouth
  • Thin, dry, peeling skin with confluent areas of hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation
  • Dry, dull, hypopigmented hair that falls out or is easily plucked
  • Hepatomegaly (from fatty liver infiltrates)
  • Distended abdomen with dilated intestinal loops
  • Bradycardia, hypotension, and hypothermia
  • Despite generalized edema, most children have loose inner inguinal skin folds
  • Intermittent periods of adequate dietary intake restores hair color, occasionally resulting in alternating loss of hair color interspersed between bands of normal pigmentation ("flag sign").
  • Stunting (reduced height for age) is often superimposed on both marasmus and kwashiorkor, reflecting not only inadequate caloric intake but also the cumulative effects of chronic poverty, food insecurity, and infectious risks that these children face.
  • Some children have features of both marasmus and kwashiorkor, sometimes known as marasmic kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor triad (hallmark features):

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1346

questions.text: After a 12-hour duty as a medical intern, you are going to pack and leave emergency room, when you notice a previously diagnosed child with Kwashiorkor being brought to pediatric emergency room. The child is in shock and has hypotension. You call up your senior, who advises to start fluids till he comes and helps in management. Which among the following is the fluid of choice you will consider in such a scenario?
questions.solution:
Fluid management in children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM): As a result of the reductive adaptive state in SAM, there is high intracellular sodium and low potassium. Thus, there is high risk of fluid overload and sodium retention with overzealous management of shock and dehydration. All children with severe acute malnutrition on intravenous or oral rehydration should be closely monitored for signs of over hydration.


Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1346 and National SAM guidelines and IMNCI 2020

questions.text: A child was being evaluated for facial dysmorphism. Karyotyping will be useful to diagnose all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
KARYOTYPING GENETICS: -

DOWN'S SYNDROME- TRISOMY CHROMOSOME 21

KLINEFELTER SYNDROME- XXY

TURNER SYNDROME- XO

NOONAN SYNDROME- is nearly always an autosomal-dominant condition.

Genetic testing-Molecular confirmation of the clinical diagnosis of NS is possible through genetic testing. "Noonan syndrome" or "RASopathy" panel test includes many or all of the genes known to be mutated in NS- protein tyrosine phosphatase, nonreceptor type 11 (PTPN11), leucine zipper-like transcription regulator 1 (LZTR1). A number of candidate genes for NS have been identified using high-throughput technologies such as exome sequencing.


Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) page no. 2995

questions.text: Down syndrome children have decreased risk of developing the following as compared to general population?
questions.solution:
Conditions Less Prevalent in Down Syndrome than General Population

  • Also called negative/protective association. Solid tumours: Neuroblastoma, Wilms tumour in children is less common in Down syndrome than in the general population. In the case of adults, the epithelial tumour is less common in Down syndrome adults than in the general population. Ischemic heart disease: The chances of ischemic heart disease during adolescence are lesser than the general population.
  • "Like other tumors, such as leukemias, testicular germ cell tumors and lymphomas are in excess in DS patients; the lack of neuroblastomas does not reflect a general decreased incidence of cancer but rather a specific underrepresentation of this precise tumor. S-100 b protein, the gene for which maps to the long arm of chromosome 21, (a) is overproduced in DS patients, (b) produces growth inhibition and differentiation of neural cells in vitro, (c) is abundant in good-prognosis neuroblastomas, and (d) has been shown to induce growth inhibition and differentiation and cell death in several human and murine neuroblastoma cell lines and could be responsible for this variation.

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) page 659

choices.text: Hypertrophy of Leydig cells in testes

questions.text: All of the following are consistent with Klinefelter Syndrome except?
questions.solution:
• Developmental stages and most common clinical presentation(s) at time of diagnosis

  • Biochemical findings- characteristic laboratory findings in men and boys older than pubertal age are the following:
    • low serum total and freen testosterone
    • high follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and high luteinizing hormone (LH) concentrations
    • high serum sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) concentrations

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2996

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with high chills with fever, hepatosplenomegaly and a lesion as shown in the picture. Peripheral blood showed hyponatremia, thrombocytopenia and transaminitis. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
• Rickettsial infections are caused by a variety of obligate intracellular, gram-negative bacteria from the genera Rickettsia, Orientia, Ehrlichia, Neorickettsia, Neoehrlichia, and Anaplasma.
  • Rickettsial diseases are zoonoses where human beings are accidentally involved in a chain of transmission between trombiculid mites (chiggers), ticks or fleas and animals (most commonly rodents).

Clinical Features-Acute fever is the most common presenting symptom, breathlessness, cough, nausea, vomiting, myalgia and headache

  • Eschar at the site of chigger bite. Eschars are painless, ulcers upto 1 cm in size, with a black necrotic centre (resembling the mark of a cigarette burn).
  • Complications -Jaundice, renal failure, pneumonitis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), septic shock, myocarditis and meningoencephalitis

Features:

Acute undifferentiated febrile illness of 5 days or more with or without eschar should be suspected as a case of Rickettsial infection.

  • Associated with headache and rash
  • lymphadenopathy
  • multi-organ involvement like liver, lung and kidney involvement.
  • Weil Felix test titres of 1:80 or above in OX2, OX19 and OXK antigens
  • Molecular diagnosis by PCR - Rickettsial DNA in eschar samples/whole blood
  • Indirect Immunoperoxidase Assay (IPA) and Immunofluorescence Assay (IFA)- serological gold standards
  • IgM and IgG ELISA: ELISA techniques, particularly immunoglobulin M (IgM) capture assays
  • Supportive laboratory Investigations
    • Total Leucocytes Count elevated
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Raised Transaminase levels
  • Imaging-Chest X-Ray showing infiltrates, mostly bilateral. (S/O ARDS)
  • Treatment:
    • Doxycycline - 4.5 mg/kg body weight/day in two divided doses for children below 45 kg Or
    • Azithromycin in the single dose of 10mg/kg body weight for 5 days.

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1627

questions.text: A 2-day-old term neonate was found to have blotchy erythematous papules on chest, with a few yellow-white lesions on day 2 of life, as shown in the image. Palms and soles were spared. There were no other significant complaints. Eosinophils were found in the intralesional smears stained with Wright's stain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Transient Neonatal Skin Lesions


  • Milia- Milia are white papules caused by retention of keratin and sebaceous material in the pilosebaceous follicles. They are frequently found on the nose and cheeks and resolve in the first few months of life
  • Miliaria-Miliaria is a transient cutaneous eruption in newborns and infants due to obstruction of sweat ducts. Hot and humid environments are particularly common causes.
  • Erythema toxicum neonatorum- Erythema toxicum neonatorum is a common pustular eruption seen more commonly in term neonates within the first 72 hours of life that resolves spontaneously within one week.
  • Clinical presentation- presents with multiple erythematous macules and papules (1 to 3 mm in diameter) that rapidly progress to pustules on an erythematous base. The lesions are distributed over the trunk and proximal extremities, sparing the palms and soles. The rash usually resolves in five to seven days.
  • Diagnosis- clinical, can be confirmed by microscopic examination of a Wright-stained smear of the contents of a pustule that demonstrates numerous eosinophils and occasional neutrophils.
  • Management-Resolves spontaneously. No treatment is necessary.
  • Transient neonatal pustular melanosis-
    • Clinical presentation-consists of three types of lesions
      • Small pustules on a nonerythematous base
      • Pink-red to brown-black macules with a surrounding collarette of scale
      • Brown-black macules
    • Diagnosis-Clinical. Microscopic examination of a Wright-stained smear of the contents of a pustule demonstrates numerous neutrophils
    • Management-No treatment is necessary.
  • Congenital Dermal melanocytosis - formerly called Mongolian spot. It typically appears as a blue-gray/ greenish-blue/ brown, pigmented patch with ill-defined borders. The diameter of the lesion may be 10 cm or more. The most common location is the sacral-gluteal region, followed by the shoulders. Lesion is completely benign and usually fades during the first or second year of life. The lesions result from the delayed disappearance of dermal melanocytes. A biopsy, which is rarely indicated, shows the widely spaced dermal melanocytes in the deep dermis

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2, 21st Edition (International Edition) page 3454

questions.text: Which of the following is used to monitor response to therapy in a patient of severe congenital CMV, who is being treated with ganciclovir?
questions.solution:
CMV antigenemia assays

  • Permit rapid and direct detection of CMV proteins (pp65) in peripheral blood leukocytes.
  • Detection of pp65 antigen-a marker of active viral replication.
  • This technique employs fluorescently labeled monoclonal antibodies specific to pp65 lower matrix protein of CMV in peripheral blood polymorphonuclear leukocytes.
  • The antigenemia test is more sensitive than culture for the detection of CMV in blood
  • CMV quantification methodologies, such as pp65 antigen detection and real-time PCR, are of high value in monitoring and detecting active infection.
  • A higher number of positive cells correlates with risk of developing active disease (10 to 20 positive cells/200,000 leukocytes).

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1, 21st Edition (International Edition) pg 1718

questions.text: A child has recently learnt to copy the image as shown below. Assuming that the child's development is proceeding normally, what other thing the child will be able to do at this age?
questions.solution:
Fine motor milestones:


Pediatric Milestone Mnemonic

All of the speech and language developmental milestones can be remembered using the age of the child.

3 Months = "3" Letter Word "Coo"

6 Months = "6" Letter Word "Babble"

9 Months = "9" Letter Word "Imitation"

12 Months = "1-2" Words

18 Months = "18" Words

2 Years = "2" Word Phrases

3 Years = "3" Word Phrases

4 Years = "4 or More" Word Sentences

Reference: Illingworth's The Development of the Infant and Young Child: Normal and Abnormal, 11edition, page 120

questions.text: Not a component of VACTERL syndrome?
questions.solution: Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1, 21st Edition (International Edition) pg 1346

choices.text: Send back home after starting oral antibiotics

questions.text: A mother brings her 9-month-old child to hospital. The child is having RR of 58/min but no chest retractions or other signs. You diagnose the child as pneumonia. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Reference: IMNCI 2020 guidelines

questions.text: Intussusception was a known complication of which of the following vaccines?
questions.solution:
• Rotavirus is responsible for the more severe forms of diarrhoea, especially in infants and very young children.
  • Almost one-third to half of all diarrhea hospitalizations in India, is caused by the rotavirus.
  • Very rarely, the rotavirus vaccine may cause Intussusception. This may present as excessive, incessant crying and blood in stools.
  • The first dose must be administered before 15 weeks of age and the last dose must be administered by 8 months of age.
  • Schedule- 6-10-14 weeks
  • Contraindications:
    • Any infant who has had an allergic reaction after a previous dose of rotavirus vaccine, or has any severe, life threatening allergies to any vaccine component.
    • Any infant with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), should not receive the vaccine.
    • Any infant with a previous episode of intussusception, should not receive the vaccine.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1, 21st Edition (International Edition) pg 1747

questions.text: A 2-year-old child has recently been diagnosed as a case of febrile seizures. The parents are concerned about the likelihood of developing epilepsy in later life. All of the following shall carry a risk greater than 10% of future epilepsy in a child with febrile seizures, except?
questions.solution:
Risk Factors for Future Epilepsy in FS


Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 3086

choices.text: Any of the above can be done

questions.text: An infant has just been diagnosed as a case of TOF. Since corrective surgery was not immediately possible, you planned for a palliative procedure. What shall be correct regarding the procedure of choice in this child for palliation?
questions.solution:
• Few patients with Tetralogy of Fallot require early surgical or transcatheter palliative intervention before complete repair is performed.
  • Palliative intervention allows deferral of elective complete repair by providing stable pulmonary blood flow required for survival.
  • Palliative intervention has traditionally consisted of surgical placement of a systemic-to-pulmonary connection.
  • Indications-Patients selected for early palliative intervention may include:
    • Infants with severe RVOT obstruction
    • Infants who are too small to undergo complete repair (eg, preterm infants)
    • Infants with a medically refractory severe hypercyanotic ("tet") spell
    • Infants with coronary anatomy complicating initial complete repair in the neonatal period
    • Infants with PA hypoplasia who would not tolerate biventricular repair
  • Surgical shunts- Palliative shunts include the modified Blalock-Thomas-Taussig shunt (mBTTS) and central shunts. In the mBTTS, a synthetic graft is placed from the innominate or subclavian artery to the ipsilateral PA.

The Blalock-Thomas-Taussig shunt (also commonly called the Blalock-Taussig shunt)


(A) Right-sided classic Blalock-Thomas-Taussig shunt.

(B) Right-sided modified Blalock-Thomas-Taussig shunt, which uses a Dacron tube to create the communication between the subclavian artery and pulmonary artery.

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2396

choices.text: Get a hemogram and throat swab done

questions.text: A 5-month old baby has intermittent stridor and dysphagia since birth. The symptoms have been present since birth and are exacerbated when child is crying or in supine position and decreased when lying down in prone position and not crying. What is the treatment?
questions.solution: Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2207

questions.text: A 6-year-old female child presented with non-blanchable petechial rash on lower limbs and buttocks, along with 3+ urinary protein and joint pains in knee and ankle. There was a preceding sore throat 2 weeks back, which was adequately treated with oral macrolides. What is the therapy of choice?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis- Immunoglobulin A vasculitis (IgAV), formerly called Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)

Epidemiology-most common systemic vasculitis of childhood.

  • IgAV occurs primarily between the ages of 3 and 15 years.
  • Peak incidence in children between 4 to 6 years age.

Pathogenesis-Immune-mediated vasculitis

  • Clinical manifestations- IgAV is a self-limited disease and is characterized by a tetrad of clinical manifestations Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy
  • Arthralgia and/or arthritis
  • Abdominal pain
  • Kidney disease
  • Diagnosis-clinical.

Biopsy of the affected organ (eg, skin or kidney) -IgA deposition




Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1319

choices.text: Caused due to autosomal recessive condition involving SLC39A4 gene
Low alkaline phosphatase levels are seen

questions.text: Which among the following statement is FALSE regarding the child shown in picture, if the child has perioral, perianal rash and has a micronutrient deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a role in growth, tissue repair and wound healing, intestinal mucosal integrity, synthesis of testicular hormones, and the immune response.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a recessively inherited partial defect in intestinal zinc absorption due to mutations in the SLC39A4gene, which encodes a protein that appears to be involved in zinc transport.
  • Moist erythematous plaques are present on the cheeks and buttocks. The buttock lesions are typically symmetric.
  • Affected infants develop an erythematous and vesiculobullous dermatitis, alopecia, diarrhea, ophthalmic disorders (including corneal scarring, cataract formation, retinal degeneration, and optic atrophy, severe growth retardation, delayed sexual maturation, neuropsychiatric manifestations, and frequent infections.
  • The syndrome is associated with severe zinc depletion and responds to oral supplementation with pharmacologic doses of zinc.
  • For acrodermatitis enteropathica, higher replacement doses are recommended: approximately 3 mg/kg/day of elemental zinc.

Hence, not Copper but Zinc supplements are useful..

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 3587

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the urgent care center after an episode during which he stopped breathing, turned blue, became limp, and stiffened. The episode lasted for about 1 minute, after which, he was very sleepy. The boy had been playing in a park when he fell, scraped his knee, and immediately cried. He then became apneic, cyanotic, and limp; lost consciousness. He has had no recent illness. There is no known family history of syncope, sudden death, or epilepsy. Of the following, based on this boy's history, the MOST likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Breath-holding spells (BHSs) are common non epileptic paroxysmal events in children. They are brief periods when young children stop breathing for <1 minute. The term appears to be a misnomer, as the spell is a reflex occurring involuntarily during expiration.


  • Average age of presentation is age 6 months upto 5 years.
  • Crying and pain are the most common triggering factors (80-85%).
  • Classified as cyanotic or pallid spell, based on the child's face (lips) during the
  • Cyanotic BHS are the most common type (72%)
  • In response to a reprimand, the child usually emits a short and loud cry, which leads to sudden involuntary holding of the breath in forced expiration. The affected child becomes cyanosed rapidly, faster than anticipated with simple breathholding.
  • The child becomes rigid and limp followed by a transient loss of consciousness. Rarely, the child may throw seizures, if apnea is prolonged.
  • Pallid BHSs are more often precipitation by pain; crying may be minimal with brief apnea, often a deep gasp followed bylossofconsciousness(LOC)andposturing.
  • The episode proceeds in same manner like cyanotic spell except that the child here develops pallor rather than cyanosis.

Treatment

  • No definite
  • Iron supplementation- controls both the frequency and severity of the spells.
  • Iron treatment has been effective in BHS children with or without anemia.
  • Piracetam prophylaxis @40mg/kg/day in children with severe and repeated BHS.
  • Usually, kids have normal intelligence quotient (IQ) with excellent

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 241

questions.text: As per neonatal resuscitation guidelines, chest compressions are initiated with PPV when heart rate dips below?
questions.solution:
Neonatal resuscitation algorithm


Reference: NRP Guidelines-American Heart Association and PALS guidelines

questions.text: Dose recommended of Paracetamol for pediatric fever is?
questions.solution:
• Oral: Weight-directed dosing: Infants, Children, and Adolescents: 10 to 15 mg/kg/dose every 4 to 6 hours as needed (Not to exceed 5 doses in 24 hours; maximum daily dose: 75 mg/kg/day not to exceed 4,000 mg/day).
  • Rectal: Weight-directed dosing: Infants and Children <12 years: 10 to 20 mg/kg/dose every 4 to 6 hours as needed; not to exceed 5 doses in 24 hours; maximum daily dose: 75 mg/kg/day not to exceed 1,625 mg/day.
  • IV:
    • Infants and Children <2 years:
      • Pain and fever: 7.5 to 15 mg/kg/dose every 6 hours; maximum daily dose: 60 mg/kg/day
    • Children ≥2 years:
      • <50 kg: 15 mg/kg/dose every 6 hours or 12.5 mg/kg/dose every 4 hours; maximum daily dose: 75 mg/kg/day not to exceed 3,750 mg/day.
      • ≥50 kg: 15 mg/kg/dose every 6 hours or 12.5 mg/kg/dose every 4 hours; maximum daily dose: 75 mg/kg/day not to exceed 4,000 mg/day.

Fever- The Clinical Hallmark of most infections

Definitions for Fever

  • Rectal Temperature > 38° C (100.4° F)
  • Oral Temperature > 37.5° C (99.5° F)
  • Axillary Temperature > 37.2° C (99° F)

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1387

questions.text: A 5-year-old child develops fever with rash. Rash is itchy and starts on trunk and disappears after few days with the child developing ataxia. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection/ Chicken pox



Complications:

  • Mild thrombocytopenia (1-2%): Rarely complicated with hemorrhage and gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding
  • Secondary bacterial infections: Mainly by group A Streptococcus and Staphylococcus aureus
  • Encephalitis: (Infrequent complication) 1 in 50,000 cases of varicella in unvaccinated children
  • Cerebellar ataxia: [Most common central nervous system (CNS) manifestation] 1 in 4,000 cases of varicella in unvaccinated children
  • Pneumonia: Primary varicella pneumonia in adults, secondary bacterial pneumonia in children
  • Progressive varicella: Seen in severely immunocompromised (absolute lymphocyte count <500) involving visceral organ
  • Herpes zoster: Occurs mostly in adults and elderly complicated by postherpetic

Others: Nephritis, nephrotic syndrome, aseptic meningitis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, transverse myelitis, arthritis, myocarditis, pericarditis, pancreatitis, orchitis, and hepatitis

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1711

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child presented with a boil on the leg 2 weeks ago and is now presenting with cola coloured urine, 2+ urinary protein, facial edema and has BP of 120/80 mm of Hg. There is no other symptom or rash. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Acute GN occurring after infection with nephritogenic strains of group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus is the prototype in children, especially from developing countries.
  • Affects children 5-12 years of age; rare below 3 years;
  • Presentation after 1-2 weeks after sore throat or 2-4 weeks after impetigo
  • Pathological hallmarks include diffuse proliferation of glomerular endothelial and mesangial cells, neutrophilic infiltration, granular capillary wall and mesangial deposits of immunoglobulin G (IgG) and C3 on immunofluorescence and subepithelial deposits (humps) on electron microscopy.

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2722

questions.text: A female neonate at birth had ambiguous genitalia. Suspecting CAH, she was evaluated and found to have high 17- hydroxyprogesterone, high progesterone and low cortisol. Likely enzyme deficient?
questions.solution:
Pathways of steroid biosynthesis


Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2970

questions.text: A neonate found to have the following at birth, along with birth weight of 4.1 kg. What metabolic abnormalities will you look for?
questions.solution:
Neonatal complications in infants born to mothers with diabetes mellitus


Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 907

questions.text: Petechiae on junction of soft and hard palate are seen in?
questions.solution:
• Infectious mononucleosis (IM) is a common viral illness characterized primarily by fever, sore throat, generalized lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and malaise.
  • Infectious mononucleosis (IM) is characterized by a triad of:

  • It is caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) (human herpes virus type IV) type 1 and 2
  • Transmitted through body fluids, especially saliva,intense personal contact with shedders and poor hygiene.
  • In children sharing toys, utensils, etc., on which they have drooled are important sources.
  • Primary infection- EBV mainly infects both oral epithelial cells and tonsillar B lymphocytes ----→ dissemination of infected B lymphocytes in peripheral blood and lymphoreticular system.
  • History of sore throat is often accompanied by pharyngeal inflammation and tonsillar exudates. Palatal petechiae with streaky hemorrhages and blotchy red macules are occasionally present.

Various clinical features are :


Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1715

questions.text: What is APGAR score of an infant which has irregular Respiratory efforts, Heart rate < 100, Body pink with blue Extremity, Muscle tone Flaccid and No response on stimulation?
questions.solution:
APGAR score-

  • Universally accepted method to assess the status of the newborn infant immediately after birth.
  • Score is assessed at one and five minutes after birth. If the five-minute score is ≤6, a 10-minute score should be assessed.
  • SCORE: 0-3(Severely depressed), 4-6(Moderately depressed), 7-10(Normal)

APGAR SCORE


Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 872

questions.text: According to the latest NACO guidelines, what shall be the investigation of choice for a 6 month old infant where you want to check for HIV status?
questions.solution: Reference: AIIMS Neonatology protocol Edition 3rd Edition 321

questions.text: An infant had refractory hypocalcemia in first few weeks of life and was diagnosed with congenital hypoparathyroidism. The child was referred to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation and also evaluated for a microdeletion defect. Which other clinical manifestation will often be present in such a child?
questions.solution:
• Thymic defects in DGS result in a range of T cell deficits.
  • Immunodeficiency is common in patients with DGS and can range from prolonged and recurrent sinopulmonary infections (often termed partial DGS) to congenital athymia (a severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] like phenotype termed complete DGS).

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1113

questions.text: A child was suspected of septic shock. He was admitted and IV access was obtained. What is the immediate next step in the management?
questions.solution: Reference: Pediatric ALS guidelines-AHA-2023

questions.text: In a normal child who weighs 24 kg, the daily fluid maintenance requirement will be approximately?
questions.solution:
Maintenance fluid calculation


In question 24 kg child- Total maintenance fluid for 24 hours = (10*100) +(10*50) +(4*20) =1580 ml

Reference: IMNCI guidelines 2020

choices.text: It most commonly occurs in first born male child
It usually presents at 3 to 4 weeks of life
Baby is hungry soon after vomiting
Feeding is followed by bilious vomiting

questions.text: Regarding congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis of infancy, which is not correct?
questions.solution:
Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is a disorder of young infants caused by hypertrophy of the pylorus, which can progress to near-complete obstruction of the gastric outlet, leading to forceful vomiting.

Incidence of IHPS is associated with:

  • Male sex - Male: female ratio approximately 5:1
  • Preterm birth
  • First born
  • Younger maternal age

Typical presentation-

  • IHPS typically presents with immediate postprandial vomiting in an infant between two and six weeks of age
  • Rarely presents after 12 weeks of age.
  • The vomiting is nonbilious and forceful ("projectile") with associated weight loss as symptoms progress.

Later presentation (classic)-

  • Infants who are identified later in the disease course -more severe symptoms, including marked weight loss and dehydration.
  • Classically described features are an infant demanding to be refed soon after vomiting (a "hungry vomiter") and intestinal peristalsis visible through the thin abdominal wall.
  • hypochloremic, metabolic alkalosis, Hypokalemia
  • palpable pyloric "olive"

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 1946

questions.text: A neonate delivered via normal vaginal delivery is started on mother's feed. He developed vomiting, hypoglycemia, oil drop cataract, hepatomegaly and mild icterus. Urine was positive for reducing substance, but no glucose. The likely enzyme deficiency is?
questions.solution:
• Galactosemia can result from deficiencies of three different enzymes

Metabolic pathway of galactose


  • Classic galactosemia is caused by complete deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).
  • Autosomal recessive disorder
  • Incidence- 1 in 60,000 livebirths
  • Infants with classic galactosemia usually present in the first few days after initiation of galactose-containing human breast milk or cow's milk-based feedings.
  • Signs and symptoms include jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, poor feeding, oil drop cataract, lethargy, diarrhea, and sepsis (particularly due to Escherichia coli).
  • Diagnosis of classic galactosemia - Quantitative assay of red blood cell (RBC) GALT activity, Genetic testing
  • The most common feature of galactokinase (GALK) deficiency is lenticular cataracts.
  • Newborn screening (NBS) for galactosemia should be done.
  • Newborns with a positive screening test for galactosemia should be changed immediately to a soy-based infant formula pending confirmation of the diagnosis. 

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2762

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match for GSD and enzymes?
questions.solution:
Glycogen Storage Diseases


Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 777

questions.text: Most common cause of death in a child of Kawasaki Disease between 3rd to 6th week of illness?
questions.solution:
Complications of Kawasaki disease

CAA: coronary artery abnormality; IVIG: intravenous immune globulin; ESR: erythrocyte sedimentation rate; KD: Kawasaki disease; GI: gastrointestinal.

  • Mortality due to KD is rare among children treated with intravenous immune globulin(IVIG).
  • Long-term morbidity is primarily related to the degree of coronary artery (CA) involvement. Recurrence of KD is uncommon.
  • Most common cause of death in a child of Kawasaki Disease between 3rd to 6th week of illness- Thrombosis of CAA

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1310

questions.text: All of the following drugs can be used to reduce the risk of painful vaso-occlusive crisis in a child with Sickle Cell Anemia (SCA), except?
questions.solution:
PREVENTION AND TREATMENT OF VASOOCCLUSIVE EVENTS AND THEIR COMPLICATIONS

Hydroxyurea and other disease-modifying agents (FDA approved)

  • Hydroxyurea - Should be offered to all adults and children with Hb SS and Hb S beta0thalassemia at nine months of age,since it reduces the incidence of acute vaso-occlusive pain episodes and other vaso-occlusive events including acute chest syndrome and in some cases stroke; decreases hospitalization rates; and prolongs survival.
  • L-glutamine- May be offered to children ≥5 years or adults who continue to have pain episodes despite hydroxyurea or who cannot take hydroxyurea.
  • Crizanlizumab- May be offered to adolescents ≥16 years or adults who continue to have pain episodes despite hydroxyurea or who cannot take hydroxyurea.
  • Voxelotor- May be offered to children ≥4 years or adults who have symptomatic or severe anemia related to their SCD.

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2541

questions.text: Moro's reflex is abnormal if persists after?
questions.solution:
Moro reflex

  • Moro reflex is elicited by the sudden dropping of the infant's head in relation to the trunk.
  • It results in abduction and extension of the infant's arms and opening of the hands, followed by flexion
  • It is present starting at 32 weeks gestation, well-established by 37 weeks gestation, and disappears by three to six months of age.
  • In normal infants Moro's reflex disappears after 24 weeks.

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 3059

questions.text: A 5-year-old unimmunized child presented with high fever, malaise, cough and redness over tonsils, evolving into a white membrane. Image of the child is shown. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diphtheria

  • Cause: Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Incubation Period: 2-5 days
  • MC Type: Faucial Diphtheria- Greyish-white pseudo- membrane forms on the tonsils.
  • Bull neck appearance due to enlarged cervical lymph nodes
  • Treatment: Antitoxin + Antibiotics

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1438

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is found to have the following deformity in both the hand bilaterally, along with mid-face hypoplasia. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Craniosynostosis Syndromes

Craniosynostosis, - premature fusion or growth arrest at one or more of the cranial sutures,

  • Apert syndrome- Craniofacial features of Apert syndrome (acrocephalosyndactyly type I) include bicoronal synostosis, maxillary hypoplasia, protruding eyes with a laterally down-sloping slant, hypertelorism, low-set ears, and high-arched palate. Additional features may include intellectual disability, strabismus, hearing loss, severe acne, and syndactyly of the hands and feet.
  • Crouzon syndrome- Craniofacial features of Crouzon syndrome (craniofacial dysostosis type I) include bicoronal synostosis, proptosis, and midface hypoplasia. The hands are typically normal, as is intelligence.
  • Pfeiffer syndrome- Craniofacial features of Pfeiffer syndrome (acrocephalosyndactyly type V) include variable degrees of craniosynostosis, midface hypoplasia, and proptosis. The presence and extent of syndactyly is variable. Additional manifestations may include broad thumbs and great toes, radiohumeral synostosis, hydrocephalus, and imperforate anus. Type 1 is mild. Types 2 and 3 are associated with severe neurologic defects that lead to early death
  • Carpenter syndrome- Craniofacial features of Carpenter syndrome (acrocephalopolysyndactyly type II) include coronal, sagittal, and lambdoid craniosynostosis; shallow supraorbital ridges; flat nasal bridge; laterally displaced lateral canthi; hypoplastic mandible and/or maxilla; low-set and malformed ears; and narrow, high-arched palate. Additional features may include abnormalities of the digits (supernumerary, short, curved, permanent flexion), cardiovascular anomalies, hypogonadism, omphalocele, and obesity.
  • Saethre-Chotzen syndrome- Craniofacial features of Saethre-Chotzen syndrome (acrocephalosyndactyly type III) include craniosynostosis of coronal, lambdoid, and/or metopic sutures, towering (turricephalic) forehead, low-set hairline, facial asymmetry with septal deviation, and ptosis. Many patients often have partial syndactyly.

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 3081

questions.text: A neonate was born at 32 weeks and developed RR of 70/min expiratory grunting. Appropriate next step will be?
questions.solution:
A total score of:

0 suggests no distress,

score of 1-4 mild RD,

score of 5-7 moderate RD

score of >7 severe distress or impending respiratory failure

Reference: Cloherty and Stark's Manual of Neonatal Care South Asian Edition, pg 5

questions.text: On evaluation of a child referred in view of periorbital edema, a urine dipstick examination was performed and the dipstick showed urine protein of 3+. This value translates to how much of urinary protein?
questions.solution:
As per Nelson 21st Ed

Urine dipstick examination for urinary protein is reported as

  • Negative: 0
  • Trace: 10-29 mg/dL
  • 1+: 30-100 mg/dL
  • 2+: 100-300 mg/dL
  • 3+: 300-1000 mg/dL
  • 4+: >1000 mg/dL

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2752

questions.text: Which among the following is not seen during a tet spell in a child with underlying Tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
Tet spells-

  • Unrepaired TOF pt- are at risk for episodic hypercyanotic ("tet") spells
  • Transient near occlusion of the RVOT with profound cyanosis.
  • Precipitating factor- when the infant becomes agitated or upset, setting of pain, fever, anemia, and hypovolemia, as well as after a bowel movement or feeding (or, in older children with uncorrected TOF, after vigorous exercise)
  • They may occur more commonly in the morning and after feeding
  • Clinical feature- hyperpnea (rapid and deep respirations), irritability, inconsolability, and progressively severe cyanosis.
  • Recovers on squatting
  • Decreased intensity of the heart murmur during attack (due to the markedly diminished blood flow across the obstruction).

Management-

  • Place the patient in a knee-chest position.
  • Administer oxygen.
  • Intravenous (IV) fluid bolus (normal saline10 to 20 mL/kg)
  • IV morphine(0.1 mg/kg per dose)
  • Intranasal fentanylor midazolam
  • an IV beta blocker (eg, propranolol1 mg/kg per dose or esmolol0.1 mg/kg per dose).
  • If beta blocker therapy is insufficient, IV phenylephrine(bolus dose of 5 to 20 mcg/kg per dose, followed by continuous infusion).
  • If all fail, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation support (ECMO), surgical repair.

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2397

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a 12-year-old girl who is being evaluated for anemia, shows the following hematological abnormality. Which among the following should be suspected in this girl?
questions.solution:
• Deficiencies of vitamin B12 and folate can both cause megaloblastic anemia.
  • The findings on the CBC and the blood cell morphology on the peripheral blood smear are identical with both deficiencies and may include one or more of the following:
    • Anemia
    • Macrocytic red blood cells (RBCs; eg, mean corpuscular volume [MCV] >100 fL) or macro-ovalocytosis
    • Mild leukopenia and/or thrombocytopenia
    • Low reticulocyte count

Hypersegmented neutrophils on the peripheral blood smear (ie, >5 percent of neutrophils with ≥5 lobes or ≥1 percent of neutrophils with ≥6 lobes)

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2517

questions.text: Not seen in a 9-month child with nutritional rickets?
questions.solution:
Clinical features of Rickets:

  • Calcipenic and phosphopenic rickets initially manifest at the distal forearm, knee, and costochondral junctions. (sites of rapid bone growth
  • Skeletal findings-The skeletal findings are similar for calcipenic and phosphopenic rickets.

Findings of advanced rickets include:

  • Delayed closure of the fontanelles
  • Parietal and frontal bossing
  • Craniotabes (soft skull bones)
  • Enlargement of the costochondral junction visible as beading along the anterolateral aspects of the chest (the "rachitic rosary")
  • Formation of Harrison sulcus (or groove) at the lower margin of the thorax caused by the inward pull by diaphragmatic attachments of the softened lower ribs
  • Widening of the wrist and bowing of the distal radius and ulna
  • Hypoplasia of the dental enamel is a typical finding of calcipenic rickets,
  • Progressive lateral bowing of the femur and tibia

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 375

choices.text: Lack of adherence to gluten-free diet
Nutritional deficiencies not allowing gut mucosal recovery

questions.text: A 10-year old child was diagnosed as Celiac disease in view of raised TTGA and biopsy from small intestinal mucosa and thus was started on gluten-free diet. Since past 6 months, child is having persistent abdominal symptoms and TTGA levels were persistently elevated. Which among the following may be responsible?
questions.solution:
Principles of a gluten-free diet- The cornerstone of treatment of celiac disease is the lifelong elimination of gluten in the diet. Consumption of a gluten-free diet requires a major lifestyle change because gluten is contained in many common foods in a Western diet. It is important to provide written information and dietary counseling to improve compliance, ideally from a registered dietitian with expertise in this area.

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 1991

choices.text: Extra corporeal membrane oxygenation with surgery after stabilization

questions.text: A very low birth weight (VLBW) preterm baby is on ventilator for respiratory distress. Baby presents with clinical feature of necrotizing enterocolitis with perforation. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution: Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1 (International Edition) pg 950

choices.text: Effacement of foot processes of podocytes

questions.text: A 5-year old male child suffering from nephrotic syndrome is responding well to steroid therapy. What would be the most likely finding on light microscopy?
questions.solution:
Steroid therapy in Nephrotic Syndrome-Most children with idiopathic NS have minimal change disease (MCD), which is generally responsive to steroid therapy [

Clinical experience has demonstrated that the response to initial steroid therapy rather than the histologic features seen on kidney biopsy is a better predictor of long-term prognosis. patients with idiopathic NS can be defined by their response to steroid therapy as follows:

  • Steroid-sensitive NS (SSNS) - More than 90 percent of patients who respond to steroid therapy have MCD.
  • Steroid-resistant NS (SRNS) - Ten to 20 percent of children with idiopathic NS fail to respond to initial empirical steroid therapy.

Reference: 21st Edition Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 2 (International Edition) pg 2752

questions.text: Look at the image below and tell the approximate age at which this milestone is normally attained in a child?
questions.solution:
Stair-Walking Milestones


Reference: Illingworth's The Development of the Infant and Young Child: Normal and Abnormal, 11th edition, pg 120

questions.text: Fluid of choice to start on first day of life in a preterm neonate requiring IV fluids is?
questions.solution:
• Glomerular filtration rates (GFR) are low in utero and remain low at birth and gradually increase in the neonatal period.
  • All newborns undergo a diuresis in the days following birth resulting from a reduction of Total Body Water.
  • Neonates undergo a diuresis within the first 24hours after birth and therefore electrolyte additives are not required within the first 24 hours of life unless clinically indicated.
  • Preterm infants are at risk for hypoglycemia and cannot take adequate nutrition by mouth initially, intravenous dextrose is used as a glucose source

Reference: Cloherty and Stark's manual of neonatal care South Asian Edition, page 398

questions.text: Bronze baby syndrome is a complication seen in phototherapy due to which among the following?
questions.solution:
Bronze baby syndrome -

  • reversible skin condition
  • manifested by a transient dark, grayish-brown discoloration of the skin and urine.
  • It occurs in infants with cholestatic jaundice (conjugated bilirubin >2 mg/dL) treated with phototherapy
  • caused by integumentary deposition of bronze-colored pigments, due to photoisomers
  • There is no known neurotoxicity associated with this syndrome;
  • resolves without sequelae within weeks after discontinuation of phototherapy as the pigments are slowly eliminated

Reference: Cloherty and Stark's manual of neonatal care South Asian Edition, pg 250
